message: if you're on django 1.1 use django.utils.importlib.import_module

I have a Django app that ships with a default form class, but I want users to be able to swap this by putting something like ``MYAPP_FORM_CLASS = "some.custom.forms.MyForm"`` in their project's settings.py.

In myapp/settings.py I have something like

    from django.conf import settings
    FORM_CLASS = getattr(settings, 'MYAPP_FORM_CLASS', "%s.forms.MyDefaultForm" % __package__)

and in myapp/views.py I have something like

    from .settings import FORM_CLASS
    forms_module, sep, form_class = FORM_CLASS.rpartition('.')
    form = getattr(__import__(forms_module, [], [], form_class), form_class)

This works but looks kind of scary to me. Is this the way to go?
also, use rsplit(".", 1) rather than rpartition so you don't get sep
ah, cool. thanks for the heads up.
